turn.text: Would you think if materials are subpoenaed and the person does not respond, he is entitled to litigate whether Congress may secure the documents or not?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: Mr. Justice White, the Court has held that in response to a contempt citation, he can litigate whether that was within the authority of Congress.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The Court sit on that sort of proceeding?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: Yes Your Honor they do --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You must suggest to Congress that perhaps some of the subpoenas are good and some are not?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: Yes, In much the same way, some of Congress’ statutes are good and some are not as this Court sits deciding whether statutes that are passed were constitutional within their power, but that does not mean that the process of getting to the statute is defective in any way.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If you are right as I understand it, whenever somebody did not comply with the subpoena, the congressional committee could just send some police officers with a guns and break into the house and get the information?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: I have two answers to that.
It raises once more the discussion I had in response to Mr. Justice Stewart’s question and about the question whether Article 1 provides to Congress the power to take things by force.
But the second answer is that there is also a problem of distinguishing between what it should do and what the remedy is for it not doing that.
We may assume that Congress should not send someone to take it by force, that it is wrong for Congress to do that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You mean just illegally, not just by force?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: Illegally or by force, but I am willing to accept by force here.
We may assume that it is wrong for Congress to do that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And you are willing to accept illegally?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: Yes, but our response is that the remedy lies in Congress’ discipline of its own members and in the public’s discipline of Congress rather than in discipline by the judicial branch of Congress’ errors.
That ultimately is our position.
I would like to address for a moment Mr. Justice Stevens, your question about the Gravel case, about the source of the documents.
It is true that the legislative aide in Gravel could be questioned about the source of the documents.
We think that is so for the same reason the Court held that the publication of the Pentagon papers was no privileged.
That is the essential holding of that case is generating publicity for its own sake is not something that is within Congress’ powers under Article 1.

Therefore, the obtaining of that document for that purpose was not a legislative act, and therefore, the immunity did not apply, but in this case, it is clear that Brick was attempting to gather information for the purpose of legislation so that his activities are a legislative act and this is therefore quite a different case from Gravel.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If we were to hold and conclude that there was not Fourth Amendment violation here, what would be the consequence on the case?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice if there were no Fourth Amendment violation, the judgment of the Court of Appeals should be reversed and the complaint dismissed although we have not raised that issue which was the subject of Judge Wilkie’s opinion.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: If we should disagree with your principle argument, what issue if any would remain for us to address?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: Mr. Justice Powell, we have raised a subsidiary argument about vicarious liability that we believe you can accept without addressing our principle argument.
Our argument about vicarious liability is that --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: I am not suggesting you go into it.
I just want to be sure you have not waived it?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: We have not waived it.
We believe very firmly that it is correct.
I just did not have time to cover it.
We argued it in our brief and we continue to argue it here.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So you are not pressing the position of the four and the Court of Appeals, the five?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: We are not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Easterbrook are any of these defendants still living?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: One of the defendants, Donald F. O’Donnell who was the chief counsel of the subcommittee is still living.
The other three defendants are deceased.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Both the senator is deceased and…

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: Mr. Alderman died in 1975 and Mr. Brick, the investigator died in 1973.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What part allegedly did the only living defendant play into this?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: He was alleged to have participated in a conspiracy with the other defendants to carry out these acts, the complaint and the affidavits of the respondents are completely nonspecific on that question.
We simply do not know what role he played.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He was not on the ground was he at the time and place of the delivery?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: He was not in Kentucky at any point.
One of our principle arguments in respect to him is the argument about vicarious liability.
He is simply being asked to answer for the misdeeds of Brick assuming that Brick had any misdeeds.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I suppose we do not have a course here in the issue of the survival of these actions?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: We do not.
The Court of Appeals reserved decision on that question and essentially asked the District Court --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But is has occurred to me that you may be asking us to decide an academic question, if these actions do not survive?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: If they do not survive, the question that remains open it would be an academic question.
In the Court of Appeals, after the deaths, the Court of Appeals asked the United States for its views and we conceded that as a matter law, the actions survive the deaths.
We have since argued that although they survived, it was necessary for the McSurelys to attempt to substitute the estates of the survivors.
The McSurelys did not do so until August 1977.
We have argued that that caused the actions to abate.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: When you concede something, is personal liability against some of the petitioners being sought which would not be indemnified by the government?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: I believe it would require a private bill to indemnify for these cases Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You have applied yourself in any sort of a conflict position then when you concede that an action survived?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: We consulted with our clients before making our concession.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In other words, Mrs. McCullen or at least derivatively she, the estate of the senator, she or whoever the beneficiaries are of that estate and you have considered would be liable?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: Your Honor, we conceded that in behalf of the estates of Alderman and O’Donnell.

After Senator McCullen died, we consulted with his estate and his estate asked us to reserve that point on his behalf and in our motion to substitute the estate for the senator to be explicitly reserved at that point and we believe that it is open for further litigation in lower Courts if that should prove necessary, but there is one very live defendant still.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, but his liability if any is asserted on quite a different ground, is it not?

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: It is asserted on the general ground of conspiracy with the others and we believe it is asserted on the same ground as to him as it is asserted with respect to Senator McCullen.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But not with respect to the --

turn.speaker: frank_h_easterbrook
turn.label: Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook
turn.text: Brick’s liability to stand on a different -- yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
